content.description:
In many literary works, relationships between siblings (brothers or sisters) create, clarify, or complicate central themes of the work. Either from your own reading or from the list, choose a work of fiction in which a sibling relationship—positive or negative—functions to deepen a central theme. Then, in a well-written essay, analyze how the sibling relationship contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

In your response you should do the following:

Respond to the prompt with a thesis that presents a defensible interpretation.

Provide evidence to support your line of reasoning.

Explain how the evidence supports your line of reasoning.

Use appropriate grammar and punctuation in communicating your argument.

Absalom, Absalom!

All the King’s Men

Antigone

Arcadia

Beloved

The Blind Assassin

The Bonesetter’s Daughter

Brideshead Revisited

The Brothers Karamazov

The Catcher in the Rye

The Comedy of Errors

Crime and Punishment

Death of a Salesman

East of Eden

Fences

The Glass Menagerie

The Grapes of Wrath

The Homecoming

Housekeeping

The Importance of Being Earnest

Just Above My Head

King Lear

The Kite Runner

The Mill on the Floss

The Piano Lesson

The Poisonwood Bible

Pride and Prejudice

A Raisin in the Sun

Sister of My Heart

Song of Solomon

The Sound and the Fury

The Story of Edgar Sawtelle

A Thousand Acres

Three Sisters

Tom Jones

The Turn of the Screw

Wuthering Heights

A Yellow Raft in Blue Water
content.question: In a well-written essay, analyze how the sibling relationship contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Describe how textual details reveal nuances and complexities in characters' relationships with one another.
